title: The Dow Is Up Ahead of Jobs News. Lululemon Gains and Beyond Meat Falls.
text:
Stocks look to finish a strong week on a positive note. So far, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is up 1.4% this week, the S&P 500 is up 1.8% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite has risen 2%.

Friday morning, stock futures were in the green again. Dow futures are up 72 points, or 0.3%, S&P futures have risen 0.2% and Nasdaq futures are 0.1% higher.

The key to whether that lasts will be the U.S. jobs report for August—a key indicator for the Federal Reserve as it considers whether to cut interest rates further this fall.

Some stock are still moving on results, reported late in the second- quarter earnings season.

Lululemon Athletica (ticker: LULU) stock rose after hours Thursday. The athletic apparel company reported strong earnings: Sales jumped 22% compared with a year ago. Shares traded above $195, or up 4%, Thursday evening.

Software provider DocuSign (DOCU) shares were also higher in premarket trading. Shares jumped 24% after the company reported stronger-than-expected sales. Another software provider, however, Domo (DOMO), didn’t fair as well. Its shares were down almost 39% after sales forecasts for the coming quarter fell short of Wall Street’s expectations.

It isn’t all about earnings and the outlook for the economy.

Beyond Meat (BYND) shares were down 2.8% in premarket trading after brokerage firm D.A. Davidson launched coverage with the equivalent of a Sell rating. The highflying food-start up closed Thursday at $160.97 a share, more than 540% above its $25 IPO price.

And stock in Facebook (FB) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) may move after The Wall Street Journal reported states’ attorneys general were about to launch an antitrust probe into the two tech giants. Facebook shares were down 1% in premarket trading, Alphabet stock is unchanged.

Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com
description: Stocks are still moving on results, reported late in the second-quarter earnings season. It isn’t all about earnings, though. States’ attorneys general are launching an antitrust probe into Facebook and Alphabet.
